clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of Food Carbohydrate and Insulin Dose Computing by on Smart Phone on Glucose Control in Patients With Diabetes
clinical_study.official_title: Assessment of the Impact of Food Carbohydrate and Insulin Dose Computing by an Application on Smart Phone on Glucose Control in Patients With Type 1 Diabetes

brief_summary.textblock: During this study, we will assess a new smart phone application which aims at helping patients with Type 1 diabetes to compute food carbohydrates and meal insulin doses. Patients, already trained to carbohydrate counting, will be recruited among those who have been using this method daily for at least 6 months. They will complete two one-month study phases, using the application in one phase and counting carbohydrate and insulin doses without the application in the other phase, with randomized order of each phase. Visits are scheduled at the start and at the end of each phase to collect data on glucose control and insulin doses. Questionnaires assessing health-related quality of life and ability of self-management of diabetes will also be filled by patients before and after each study phase.

detailed_description.textblock: During this study, we will assess a new smart phone application which aims at helping patients with Type 1 diabetes to compute food carbohydrates and meal insulin doses. Patients, already trained to carbohydrate counting, will be recruited among those who have been using this method daily for at least 6 months.

primary_outcome.measure: 2-hour postmeal blood glucose values between 80 and 180 mg/dl
primary_outcome.description: Percent 2-hour postmeal blood glucose values between 80 and 180 mg/dl during 4 weeks

secondary_outcome.description: Average 2-hour postmeal blood glucose level during 4 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Type 1 diabetes since more than 1 year
- Basal-bolus insulin regimen since more than 6 months
- Daily practice of food carbohydrate counting since more than 6 months
- HbA1c level below 12%
Exclusion Criteria:
- Type 2 diabetes
- No ability to use a smart phone
- Pregnancy or lactation
- Severe psychiatric disorders
- Eating disorders
- Alcohol abuse or recreational drug use
